message_1:
Suppose we have an algebraic variety $X$ defined over $\mathbb{C}$ with cohomology groups given by $H^i(X,\mathbb{Q}) = \begin{cases} \mathbb{Q} & \text{if } i=0 \\ 0 & \text{otherwise} \end{cases}$. Suppose also that $Y$ and $Z$ are smooth projective algebraic varieties defined over $\mathbb{C}$ such that $Y$ has dimension $m$ and $Z$ has dimension $n$. 
Using the derived category of $X$, show that $\text{Ext}^i(Y,Z)=\begin{cases} \mathbb{Q} & \text{if } i=m-n \\ 0 & \text{otherwise} \end{cases}$.
message_2:
To compute the Ext groups, we will use the derived category of coherent sheaves on $X$. Let $\mathcal{F}$ and $\mathcal{G}$ be coherent sheaves on $Y$ and $Z$, respectively. We can consider the derived functors $R^i\text{Hom}(\mathcal{F},\mathcal{G})$ in the derived category, which compute the Ext groups $\text{Ext}^i(\mathcal{F},\mathcal{G})$.

Since $Y$ and $Z$ are smooth projective varieties, we can use the Poincaré duality, which states that there is an isomorphism
$$
\text{Ext}^i(Y,Z) \cong H^{m-n-i}(Y \times Z, \mathcal{F}^\vee \boxtimes \mathcal{G}),
$$
where $\mathcal{F}^\vee$ is the dual sheaf of $\mathcal{F}$, and $\boxtimes$ denotes the external tensor product of sheaves.

Now, we are given that the cohomology of $X$ is concentrated in degree 0, i.e., $H^i(X,\mathbb{Q}) = \mathbb{Q}$ if $i=0$ and $0$ otherwise. Since $Y$ and $Z$ are defined over $\mathbb{C}$, we can assume that the same holds for their cohomology groups. Therefore, we have
$$
H^i(Y,\mathbb{Q}) = \begin{cases} \mathbb{Q} & \text{if } i=0 \\ 0 & \text{otherwise} \end{cases}
$$
and
$$
H^i(Z,\mathbb{Q}) = \begin{cases} \mathbb{Q} & \text{if } i=0 \\ 0 & \text{otherwise} \end{cases}.
$$

Using the Künneth formula for the cohomology of the product $Y \times Z$, we get
$$
H^i(Y \times Z, \mathcal{F}^\vee \boxtimes \mathcal{G}) = \bigoplus_{p+q=i} H^p(Y, \mathcal{F}^\vee) \otimes H^q(Z, \mathcal{G}).
$$

Now, we can compute the Ext groups using the Poincaré duality and the Künneth formula:
$$
\text{Ext}^i(Y,Z) \cong H^{m-n-i}(Y \times Z, \mathcal{F}^\vee \boxtimes \mathcal{G}) = \bigoplus_{p+q=m-n-i} H^p(Y, \mathcal{F}^\vee) \otimes H^q(Z, \mathcal{G}).
$$

Since the cohomology groups of $Y$ and $Z$ are concentrated in degree 0, the only non-zero term in the sum is when $p=q=0$, i.e., when $i=m-n$. In this case, we have
$$
\text{Ext}^{m-n}(Y,Z) \cong H^0(Y, \mathcal{F}^\vee) \otimes H^0(Z, \mathcal{G}) \cong \mathbb{Q}.
$$

For all other values of $i$, the sum is empty, and we have $\text{Ext}^i(Y,Z) = 0$. Therefore, we have shown that
$$
\text{Ext}^i(Y,Z) = \begin{cases} \mathbb{Q} & \text{if } i=m-n \\ 0 & \text{otherwise} \end{cases}.
$$
